G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as the original judgment was entered in this Court, the minor child resides in Massachusetts, and jurisdiction remains proper due to the continuing significant relationship between the minor child and both parents.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified where a "material and substantial change in circumstances" has occurred such that a modification is in the best interests of the child.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a custody order may be modified where a "material and substantial change in circumstances" has occurred such that a modification is in the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial divorce judgment involving custody and international removal, not a post-judgment modification of a custody order. The court discusses the best-interests standard and the ‘real advantage’ test for removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30, but nowhere articulates or applies a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement for modifying custody. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this commonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Court’s primary obligation in custody matters is to determine and promote the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames custody determinations in terms of the child’s best interests and treats that as the governing standard. The court traces the historical development of the “best interests of the child” test, calls it the touchstone inquiry in custody matters, and reiterates that the judge’s task is to determine which arrangement best promotes the child’s welfare, confirming that this is the court’s primary obligation in custody disputes.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The Court’s primary obligation in custody matters is to determine and promote the best interests of the child.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in custody determinations the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and general welfare, citing prior Massachusetts authority. The court then applies that best-interests standard to uphold the award of sole custody to the mother, confirming that this is the primary obligation guiding custody decisions.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child.”

El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 50.raw_text: El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 501 (2010)
El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 50.proposition: A significant decline in academic performance and school attendance as a direct result of a parent’s conduct constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of a custody arrangement.
El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 50.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a Lebanese custody-modification judgment should be enforced in Massachusetts under the “substantial conformity” standard of G.L. c. 209B, § 14. It does not discuss academic performance, school attendance, or what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances warranting modification of custody under Massachusetts standards. The only removal-related discussion is that unilateral removal alone is insufficient to modify custody, which is the opposite of the claimed proposition and unrelated to academic decline as a factor.
El Chaar v. Chehab, 78 Mass. App. Ct. 50.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, while removal of a child without court authorization or parental consent is a relevant consideration, the child is ‘not chargeable with the misconduct of her mother . . . and ought not to be compelled to suffer for it. Her welfare is the paramount consideration.’ … Thus, such removal by a custodial parent (with the inevitable impairment of the father’s visitation rights …) is alone insufficient to warrant modification of the custody order.”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Court has recognized that stable, consistent school attendance is a critical component of a child’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on domestic violence and its impact on a child’s best interests in custody determinations. School is mentioned only factually (that the child is doing well, the father meets with teachers) and not as a legal factor, let alone as framing stable, consistent school attendance as a critical component of the best-interests analysis. The court neither articulates nor relies on any legal principle elevating school attendance to that status.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Vaughn ‘is doing well at school. His guidance counsellor is hopeful he will continue to shine in school as he did during his last marking period.’ … The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The Court has recognized that stable, consistent school attendance is a critical component of a child’s best interests.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether separating identical twin siblings between two households is in their best interests, emphasizing the strong presumption that siblings—especially twins—should remain together. While the court notes that the twins attend school and references guidance counselors, it does not articulate any principle that stable, consistent school attendance is a critical component of a child’s best interests. The best‑interests analysis here turns on sibling unity, parental fitness, and overreliance on children’s stated preferences, not school attendance stability.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The list of factors within the judge’s purview in child custody matters includes a presumption generally favoring the placement of siblings under one roof. … We have examined both the record from the proceedings below and the judge’s notes from his private interview with Rebecca and find no evidence from which the judge properly could have concluded that a split physical custody arrangement would be in the childrens’ best interests. Indeed, the evidence … is to the contrary.”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).proposition: A breakdown in this cooperation or a failure to adequately support the child's educational needs may justify modification.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute, not about modification of custody or parenting plans based on cooperation or support of a child’s educational needs. Nowhere does the court discuss breakdowns in parental cooperation or failures to support education as grounds for modifying an order. The claimed proposition concerns standards for modification, which this case does not address at all.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649 (2002).relevant_excerpt: We conclude, in rejection of the facial due process challenge made by the mother, that the statute satisfies strict scrutiny because our construction narrowly tailors it to further the compelling State interest in protecting the welfare of a child who has experienced a disruption in the family unit from harm.

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.proposition: Massachusetts courts have broad discretion to fashion modifications to custody and parenting time arrangements that are consistent with the child's best interests.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that a probate judge has substantial discretion in making custody orders and that custody determinations are based on the child’s best interests, but it does not specifically discuss or illustrate modifications of existing custody or parenting-time orders. The case concerns an initial (post-paternity) award of sole legal and physical custody to the father, not a modification proceeding, and therefore does not directly support the proposition about courts’ broad discretion to fashion modifications to existing arrangements. It is solid authority on broad discretion in custody decisions generally, but not on modification power in particular.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . . … ‘The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests ‘is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’’ … 3. A probate judge has substantial discretion in making custody orders.”
